header.annotationScheme: Guidelines for the syntactic annotation of the Ancient Greek dependency treebank 1.1

respStmt.resp: release editor: post-annotation normalization and harmonization
responsible for the annotation environment and cts:urn technology

monogr.author: Aeschylus
monogr.title: Aeschylus, with an English translation by Herbert Weir Smyth, Ph. D. in two volumes. 1.Seven Against Thebes

imprint.publisher: Cambridge, Mass., Harvard University Press; London, William Heinemann, Ltd.

header.encodingDesc: The unannotated text comes from the digital edition of the text specified in the element monogr. The digital edition can be consulted on PerseusDL (https://github.com/PerseusDL/canonical-greekLit), looking up the cts:urn. The annotator(s) may have chosen different variants for the text.
header.profileDesc: Consult the file README.xml for the details concerning normalization and harmonization of the text, and the file TAGSETS.xml for the meaning of the labels used in the annotation. The treebanked text before normalization and harmonization can be consulted on PerseusDL (https://github.com/PerseusDL/treebank_data/tree/master/v1.6).

sentence.translation: Citizens of Cadmus, he must speak to the point who guards the state in the stern of the city, guiding the helm, not lulling his eyelids in sleep.
For if we succeed, the credit belongs to the god;

but if, on the other hand—may it not happen!—disaster should occur, Eteocles alone would be much sung of throughout the city by the citizens in clamorous preludes and wailings, from which may Zeus the Averter be true to his name for the city of the Cadmeans.

But now it is necessary for you—both him who falls short of prime youth and him who is past his prime in time, nurturing much growth of body, and each one having the season that is fitting—to aid the city and the altars of the local gods, so that their honors may never be wiped out;
and for your children, and for Earth your mother, dearest nurse.

For she, welcoming all the burden of your upbringing on her kindly soil when you were young and creeping about, reared you to be shield-bearing inhabitants, faithful so that you might prove equal to this duty.
And now, up to this day, god inclines well;
for to us being besieged for this long time already, the war turns out well for the most part by the will of the gods.
But now, as the seer says, the feeder of birds, observing with ears and mind, without fire, the prophetic birds with unerring art;
he, master of such prophecies, says that the greatest Achaean assault is being proclaimed by night and plans against the city.

But rush, all of you, to the battlements and gates of the towers, hasten with full armor, man the breastworks, and take your stand on the platforms of the towers, and remaining at the exits of the gates, take good courage, and do not fear too much the crowd of aliens;
God will accomplish it well.
And I too have sent scouts and observers of the army, who I trust are not making the journey in vain;
and having heard from them, I shall not be caught by any trick.
Eteocles, most excellent lord of the Cadmeans, I have come bringing clear news from the army there, and I myself am an eyewitness of the events.

For seven men, impetuous company-commanders, slaughtering a bull into a black-bound shield and touching the bull's gore with their hands, swore by Ares, Enyo, and blood-loving Terror, either to sack the city of the Cadmeans by force, having brought destruction upon it, or having died, to mix this land with their blood;
and they wreathed memorials of themselves for their parents at home on the chariot of Adrastus, shedding tears;
but there was no pity in their speech.
For their iron-hearted spirit, burning with courage, breathed as lions glare Ares.
And the news of these things is not delayed by hesitation;
for I left them casting lots, so that each of them, having obtained his lot, might lead his company to the gates.
Therefore appoint our best chosen men quickly at the exits of the city gates;
for already the army of Argives in full armor draws near, and raises dust, and white foam from the horses' lungs stains the plain with drops.
And you, like a careful helmsman of a ship, secure the city, before the blasts of Ares swoop down;
for the wave of the army roars on land.
And seize the opportunity for these things, which is swiftest.
And for the rest, I will have a faithful eye looking by day, and knowing the things outside by the clearness of my account, you shall be unharmed.

O Zeus and Earth and city-protecting gods, and Curse, the mighty Erinys of my father, do not root out my city, captured by the enemy, totally destroyed, pouring forth the speech of Hellas, and our hearths;
but never hold the free land and the city of Cadmus in the yoke of slavery.
But be our strength;
I hope I speak of common things.
For a city doing well honors the gods.
I shriek for fearful, great woes.
The army is let loose;
leaving the camp, this great host flows, a forerunner, mounted.
Dust in the air convinces me, appearing as a voiceless, clear, true messenger.
And yet the plains of my land, struck by hooves, bring the sound to my ear;
it flies and roars like an irresistible torrent striking a mountain.
Woe, woe, woe! Gods and goddesses, ward off the rising evil, the shout over the walls!
The white-shielded army rushes well-equipped against the city, pursuing a swift pace.
Who then will rescue, who then will help, of gods or goddesses?
Shall I then fall before the ancestral images of the gods?
Woe, blessed ones, well-seated, it is high time to cling to your images.
Why do we linger, groaning?
Do you hear or do you not hear the clash of shields?
When, if not now, shall we busy ourselves with robes and garlands of prayer?
I see the clash!
It is not the clatter of a single spear.
What will you do?
Will you betray your own land, Ares, ancient god of this land?
O god of the golden helm, look upon, look upon the city which once you took as your favorite.
Gods, all of you who hold the city, come!
See the suppliant company of maidens praying for freedom from slavery.
For a wave of warriors with slanting crests seethes around the city, stirred by the blasts of Ares.
But, O Zeus, father all-powerful, ward off capture by the enemy by all means!
The Argives are encircling the citadel of Cadmus.
And fear of martial arms shakes us, and the bits through the horse's jaws sound of slaughter.
Seven proud army-leaders, conspicuous in their spear-brandishing armor, stand at the seventh gate, assigned by lot.

And you, O Zeus-born power delighting in battle, become a city-saver, Pallas, and the horse-lord, ruler of the sea, King Poseidon with your fish-spearing machine, grant release from fears, grant release.
And you, Ares, alas, alas, guard the city named for Cadmus and care for it manifestly.
And Cypris, since you are the first mother of our race, ward off danger.
For we are born from your blood.
Calling upon you with god-hearing prayers, we approach.
And you, Wolf-lord, become a wolf to the hostile army, as a retribution for our groans.
And you, daughter of Leto, Artemis dear, prepare your bow.
Artemis dear, ah, ah, ah, ah, the air is shaken by spears and raves.
What is our city suffering, what will become of it?
And to what end does the god lead it?
Ah, ah, ah, ah, a shower of stones from the skirmishers hits the battlements.
O dear Apollo!
The din of bronze-bound shields at the gates! Son of Zeus, from whom comes the pure, war-ordained end in battle.
And you, blessed queen Onca, dwelling before the city, protect your seven-gated seat.
O all-powerful gods, O perfect gods and perfect goddesses, guardians of the towers of this land, do not betray our war-weary city to an alien-voiced army.
Hear the maidens, hear the prayers we offer with outstretched hands, most justly.
Oh dear divinities, delivering ones having taken your stand around the city, show that you are city-loving, and care for the public holy rites, and caring, bring aid.
And indeed, be mindful for me of the city's sacrificial rituals.

I ask you, creatures not to be endured, is this best and saving for the city, and confidence for this army besieged in towers, namely having fallen upon the statues of the city-protecting gods, to shout, to scream—objects of hatred to the prudent?
May I not be a co-dweller with the female race neither in evils nor in dear well-being.
For prevailing, she is a boldness not approachable, but having become afraid, she is a greater evil to home and city.
And now, having caused these running-about flights for the citizens, you have clamored out soulless cowardice.
And the affairs of those from outside are increased as best as possible, but we ourselves are destroyed from within by ourselves.
Such things indeed you would have, living together with women.
And if anyone will not obey my authority, man and woman and whatever is in between, a destructive vote shall be resolved against them, and by no means shall he escape the stoning fate of the people.
For the things outside are a care to a man—let no woman advise—;
but being inside, do not cause harm.
Did you hear or did you not hear, or do I speak to a deaf woman?
Oh dear child of Oedipus, I feared having heard the chariot-clashing din, din, and when whirling naves clanged, and the sound of horse steering-gear through the mouth, of fire-born bridles.
What then?
The sailor, then, fleeing to the prow from the stern, did he find a means of safety, the ship laboring against a sea wave?
But I came running to the ancient statues of the divinities, trusting in the gods, when the roar of a destructive snowstorm falling was at the gates.
Indeed then I was lifted by fear to supplications of the blessed ones, that they might hold protection over the city.
Pray that the tower hold off the enemy spear.
Therefore these things shall be from the gods.
But then there is a saying that the gods leave the captured city.
Never during my life may this assembly of gods leave, nor may I look upon this city being overrun and the army being kindled with hostile fire.
Do not, calling on the gods, advise badly for me.
For Obedience is the mother of Success, wife of the Savior.
Thus holds the saying.
It is so.
But the strength of god is still higher.
And often in evils, it raises up the helpless man even out of harsh misery, when clouds are hanging over his eyes.
These things are for men, to offer victims and sacrifices to the gods when making trial of the enemy.
But yours on the other hand is to be silent and to remain inside the house.
Thanks to the gods we inhabit an unconquered city, and the tower keeps off the multitude of enemies.
What indignation hates these things?
I do not indeed begrudge you to honor the race of divinities.
But so that you may not make the citizens faint-hearted, be quiet and do not fear too much excessively.
Hearing a strange clatter confusedly, with fearful terror, I came to this acropolis, a honored seat.
Do not now, if you learn of dying or wounded ones, snatch them up with wailings.
For Ares feeds on this, the slaughter of mortals.
And indeed I hear at least the snortings of horses.
Do not now, hearing clearly, hear too much.
The fortress groans from the earth, as if being encircled.
Therefore it suffices for me to plan concerning these things.
I fear, and the crashing at the gates is increased.
Will you not silently speak nothing of these things throughout the city?
Oh company, do not betray the towers.
Will you not, being silent, endure these things to destruction?
Citizen gods, may I not meet with slavery.
You yourself enslave both me and the whole city.
Oh all-powerful Zeus, turn the missile against the enemies.
Oh Zeus, what sort of race of women did you bestow!
A wretched one, just like men whose city is captured.
Do you speak ill-omen again, touching the statues?
For fear seizes my tongue in faint-heartedness.
If only you would grant a light end to me asking.
You might speak as quickly as possible, and I will know quickly.
Be silent, oh wretched one, do not frighten friends.
I am silent.
With the others I will undergo the fated thing.
I choose this word of yours instead of those.
And in addition to these things at least, being outside the statues, pray for the better things, that the gods be allies.
And having heard my prayers, then you, sing the sacred kindly shout, the Greek custom of sacrificial cry, a confidence to friends, releasing enemy fear.

And I speak to the city-protecting gods of the land, both those dwelling in the plain and overseers of the market-place, and to the springs of Dirce, and the water of Ismenus, if things happen well and the city is saved, bloodying the hearths of the gods with sheep—[I vow] to sacrifice trophies, and vestments of the enemies, I will crown spoils struck by the spear in the holy temples.
I will crown before the temples, and the vestments of the enemies.
Pray such things to the gods, not with fondness for sighing, nor in vain and wild shrieks.
For not any more will you escape the fated thing.

And I, having gone, will station six men, with myself as seventh, opponents to the enemies in the great fashion at the seven-walled exits, before messengers and swift-flowing words arrive and burn [us] by necessity.
It is a care, and because of fear my heart does not sleep.
And anxieties, neighbors of the heart, kindle dread regarding the people surrounding the walls, just as some all-trembling dove fears serpents, bad bed-fellows, on behalf of her nestling children.
For they indeed against the towers with the whole people, with the whole crowd, are marching.
What is to become of me?
And they hurl a jagged stone against the citizens thrown on both sides.
In every way, Zeus-born gods, rescue the city and the Cadmus-born army.

And what sort of soil of land better than this will you exchange, having abandoned to enemies the deep-soiled land and the Dircean water, most well-nourishing of draughts, of as many as Poseidon the earth-holder sends forth and the children of Tethys.
Therefore, oh city-protecting gods, having cast upon those outside the towers the man-destroying fate, the weapon-hurling ruin, win glory for these citizens.
And be deliverers of the city, and be well-seated, and stand with sharp-wailing prayers.

For it is pitiable to send a city thus ancient to Hades, a slave-prey of the spear in crumbling dust, being sacked by an Achaean man by the will of the gods, indignantly, and for the captured ones to be led away, alas, alas, both young and old, like horses, their robes being torn around them.
And the emptied city cries out, the booty perishing with confused noise.
Indeed I fear beforehand heavy fortunes.
And it is a weeping thing for those raw-plucked to traverse a hateful road from their homes before lawful rites.
For I declare that the dead man fares better than these.
For when a city is tamed, alas, alas, it suffers many and unfortunate things.
And one leads another, murders, and sets fire to parts.
And the whole fortress is defiled by smoke.
And Ares, raging, breathes upon it, subduing the people, polluting piety.
And there are rumblings throughout the town, and against the city a net of towers.
And man is laid low by man around the spear.
And bloody bleatings of the newly-nursed upon the breast resound.
And plunderings are sisters of runnings-about.
He, bearing it, meets with him bearing it, and empty he calls empty, wishing to have a partner, neither less nor equal eagerly desiring.
Reason is present to guess what comes from these things.
And fruit of every kind, having fallen to the ground, causes grief, having happened so.
And bitter is the eye of the store-keepers.
And many gifts of the earth, mixed indiscriminately, are carried in worthless surges.
And young slave-girls are new to misery.
Their expectation is that a night-time end will come to their enduring a captive bed of a successful man, as of a superior enemy, a helper of all-tearful pains.
The scout, I tell you, oh friends, brings some news of the army to us, as it seems to me, pursuing the guiding naves of his feet with haste.
And indeed here is the king himself, child of Oedipus, to learn the just-timed word of the messenger.
I could speak, knowing well the things of the opponents, and how each has been allotted the lot at the gates.
Tydeus indeed already rages at the Proetid gates, but the seer does not allow him to cross the Ismenian ford.
For sacrificial victims do not become favorable.
And Tydeus, raging and eager for battle, shouts like a serpent with noon-day hissings.
And he strikes the wise seer, son of Oicles, with a reproach, that he fawns upon death and battle out of faint-heartedness.
Shouting such things, he shakes three overshadowing crests, the mane of his helmet, and inside under the shield bronze-wrought bells clang out fear.
And he has this haughty sign on his shield, a fashioned sky blazing under stars.
And a bright full moon stands out in the middle of the shield, oldest of stars, eye of night.
Raving such things with his haughty armor, he shouts by the river banks, loving battle, just as a horse panting against the bridle waits, whoever waits in excitement for the cry of the trumpet.
Whom will you station against this man?
Who is a guarantee to stand before the Proetid gates when the bars are loosed?
I would not fear any ornament of a man, nor do signs become wound-inflicting.
And crests and bell do not bite without a spear.
And this night which you say is upon the shield, sparkling with stars of heaven, perhaps the folly might become a prophet to someone.
For if night should fall upon his eyes dying, to him bearing this haughty sign, it would become rightly and justly named, and he himself will prophesy this insolence against himself.
And I will station against Tydeus the trusty son of Astacus, defender of these gates, both very noble and honoring the throne of Modesty and hating haughty words.
For he is slow of base deeds, and is accustomed to be not evil.
And he is from the Sown Men, whom Ares spared, a root grown up, and is thoroughly native, Melanippus.
And Ares will decide the deed with dice.
And Justice, his blood-kin, sends him forth indeed to ward off the enemy spear from the mother who bore him.
Now may the gods grant that my champion succeed, since justly he rushes forth as a defender for the city.
But I tremble to see the bloody fates of friends perishing on behalf of friends.
To this one indeed may the gods grant to succeed thus.

But Capaneus has been allotted at the Electran gates, this other giant greater than the one mentioned before, and his boast breathes not according to man, and he threatens towers with terrible things, which may fortune not fulfill.
For he says he will sack the city whether a god is willing or not willing, and that not even the strife of Zeus, having fallen on the plain in the way, would hold him back.
And he likened lightnings and thunderbolts to noon-day heats.
And he has a sign, a naked man bearing fire, and a torch shines armed in his hands.
And he says in golden letters: 'I will burn the city.'
Send against such a man—who will stand against him, who without trembling will await a vaunting man?
Even in this gain another gain is bred.
For of vain thoughts the tongue becomes a true accuser to men.
And Capaneus threatens, prepared to act, dishonoring the gods, and exercising his mouth in vain joy, being mortal, he sends loud swelling words to Zeus in heaven.
And I trust that the fire-bearing thunderbolt will come to him with justice, in no way likened to the noon-day heats of the sun.
And against him a man, even if he is extremely mouth-bold, a burning will has been stationed, the mighty Polyphontes, a trusty bulwark, by the favor of protecting Artemis and with other gods.
Speak of another allotted at other gates.
May he perish, who boasts greatly against the city, and may the bolt of lightning check him, before he rushes into my house and ever destroys [it] from its maiden abodes with an arrogant spear.
And indeed I will speak of him allotted next at the gates.
For the third lot leaped from the upturned helmet for the third, Eteoclus, to hurl his company against the Neistan gates.
And he whirls mares snorting in their nosebands, wishing to fall against the gates.
And their muzzles whistle in a barbarian fashion, filled with nostril-boasting breaths.
And his shield has been decorated in no small fashion.
A heavily-armed man climbs the rungs of a ladder against an enemy tower, wishing to sack it.
And this man shouts in syllables of letters that not even Ares would cast him from the towers.
Send also to this man the one reliable to keep the yoke of slavery from this city.
I would send this man already, and with some fortune.

And already Megareus has been sent, having his boast in his hands, seed of Creon, of the race of the Sown Men, who fearing not the roar of mad snortings of horses will withdraw from the gates, but either having died will pay the nurse's fee to the land, or having captured both the two men and the city on the shield will adorn the house of his father with spoils.
Boast against another, and do not begrudge me, speaking.
I pray for this one to succeed, oh defender of my house, and for those to fail.
And as they speak excessive things against the city with mad mind, so may Zeus the dispenser look upon them with wrath.
Another, the fourth, stands near, holding the neighboring gates of Onca Athena, with a shout, the form and great mold of Hippomedon.
I shuddered at him whirling the large disk, I mean the circle of his shield.
I will speak not otherwise.
And the sign-maker was not someone cheap who bestowed this work on the shield, Typhon sending forth through his mouth fire-breathing black smoke, the wavering sister of fire.
And the circular hollow of the hollow-bellied shield is floored with coils of serpents.
And he himself shouted, and inspired by Ares he raves for battle, looking terror like a Thyiad.
One must guard well against the attack of such a man.
For Terror boasts already at the gates.
First of all Onca Pallas, who is near the city, neighbor to the gates, hating the insolence of the man, will ward him off like a chill serpent from her nestlings.

And Hyperbius, the trusty child of Oenops, has been chosen against this man, a man willing to inquire his fate in need of fortune, neither in form, nor in spirit, nor in the holding of arms to be blamed, but Hermes brought them together reasonably.
For the man is hostile to the man with whom he will engage, and they will bring together enemy gods on their shields.
For the one has fire-breathing Typhon, but on Hyperbius father Zeus sits erect on the shield, burning a bolt in his hand.
And no one yet saw Zeus anywhere being conquered.
Such indeed is the friendship of the divinities.
We are on the side of the victors, but they are on the side of the vanquished, if indeed Zeus is mightier than Typhon in battle.
And it is likely that the opposing men will fare thus, and Zeus on the shield might become a savior to Hyperbius according to the meaning of the sign.
I trust that he having the adversary of Zeus on his shield, the friendless form of the subterranean divinity, a likeness hateful to mortals and long-lived gods, will dash his head before the gates.
May it become thus.
And I speak again of the fifth one, stationed at the fifth Northern gates, by the tomb of Zeus-born Amphion.
And he swears by the spear which he holds, trusting to revere it more than a god and higher than his eyes, that he will truly sack the city of the Cadmeans in spite of Zeus.
This the fair-faced offspring of a mountain-dwelling mother shouts, a man-boy man.
And the down creeps just now through his cheeks, the thick hair springing up of youth growing.
And he stands near having a savage spirit, not at all named for maidens, and a grim eye.
Yet he stands at the gates not without boast.

For he wields on his bronze-wrought shield, a rounded protection for his body, the reproach of the city, the Sphinx, eating raw flesh, fastened with rivets, a bright embossed form, and she carries under her a single Cadmean man, so that most missiles are hurled at this man.
And having come, Parthenopaeus the Arcadian seems not likely to trade in battle, nor to disgrace the path of the long journey.
And such a man, a resident alien, and paying back fine nurture to Argos, threatens these towers with things which may god not fulfill.
For if they should meet with what they intend from the gods, with those very unholy boasts...
...truly they would perish utterly destroyed and in total evil.
But there is also against this one, whom you call the Arcadian, a man without boast, but his hand sees the thing to be done, Actor, brother of the one mentioned before.
Who will not allow a tongue flowing without deeds inside the gates to foster evils, nor him bearing the image of the most hateful beast, the monster, on his hostile shield to enter.
She from outside will blame the one bearing her inside, meeting with thick battering under the city.
Gods willing, I would speak the truth.
The word comes through my breast, and the lock of my hair stands upright, hearing the great things of big-talking unholy men.
For would that the gods might destroy them in the land.
I would speak of the sixth man, most prudent, and best in battle, the seer, the might of Amphiaraus.
And stationed at the Homoloid gates, he speaks many bad things against the might of Tydeus.
The manslayer, the troubler of the city, the greatest teacher of evils to Argos, summoner of the Fury, minister of slaughter, and counselor of these evils to Adrastus.
And again addressing your brother, the might of Polynices, casting his eye upward, and dividing the name twice at the end, he calls him.
And he speaks this word through his mouth:
Truly is such a deed dear to the gods, and fine to hear and to tell to those later, to sack the paternal city and the native gods, having thrown in a foreign army?
And what justice will quench the spring of a mother?
And how will the fatherland, captured by the spear through your zeal, become an ally to you?
I indeed will fatten this earth, a seer lying buried under enemy soil.
Let us fight; I do not expect a dishonorable death.
The seer spoke such things, holding his all-bronze shield quietly.
But no sign was upon the circle.
For he does not wish to seem the best, but to be, reaping a deep furrow through his mind, from which noble counsels grow.
I praise sending wise and good opponents against this one.
Strange is he who reveres the gods.
Alas for the omen associating a just man with the more impious among mortals.
In every matter indeed nothing is worse than bad company, the fruit is not to be gathered.
The field of delusion bears death as its fruit.

For either a pious man, having embarked on a ship with hot-headed sailors and some wickedness, perishes with the god-detested race of men, or being just with citizen men, both hostile to strangers and unmindful of the gods, having met with the same snare, being struck by the all-common whip of the god, he is subdued.

Thus indeed, I say, the seer, son of Oicles—a prudent, just, good, pious man, a great prophet—having mingled with unholy, bold-mouthed men against his judgment, stretching out a long procession to go back, Zeus willing, he will be dragged down together.
I think indeed, then, that he will not attack the gates, not as fainthearted nor by cowardice of will, but he knows how he must end in battle, if there will be fruit to the oracles of Loxias.
And he is accustomed to be silent or to speak timely things.

Nevertheless against him we will station a man, the might of Lasthenes, a gate-keeper hostile to strangers, old in mind, but he grows youthful flesh, swift of foot in his eye, and his hand is not slow to snatch the spear laid bare from the shield.
But success for mortals is a gift of god.
Hearing our just prayers, fulfill them, oh gods, so that the city may succeed, turning aside laboring evils of the spear into the invaders of the land.
And may Zeus kill him with a thunderbolt, having cast him outside the towers.
I will speak of this seventh one indeed at the seventh gates, your own brother, what sort of fortunes he curses and prays down upon the city.

Having mounted the towers and having been proclaimed to the land, having shouted the paean of capture, [he prays] to clash with you and, killing, to die nearby, or to punish you, the dishonorer, the banisher, alive in the same fashion with exile.
Such things he shouts, and the might of Polynices calls the ancestral gods of his fatherland to be supervisors of his prayers completely.
And he has a newly-constructed well-rounded shield and a double sign fastened to it.
For a certain woman leading prudently leads a man beaten in gold, a warrior to behold.
And she says she is Justice, as the letters speak: 'And I will bring back this man, and he will have his city and access to his paternal home.'
Such are the inventions of those men.
But do you yourself know now whom it seems best to send.
For you will never blame this man for his reports, but you yourself know how to pilot the city.
Oh maddened by god and great hatred of the gods, oh my all-tearful race of Oedipus.
Alas, now indeed the curses of my father are brought to pass.
But it is fitting neither to weep nor to wail, lest a harder lament be born.
But to the one truly named, to Polynices I say, we shall soon know where the emblem will end, if the gold-wrought letters babbling on his shield with madness of mind will bring him back.
But if the maiden Justice, child of Zeus, were present in his deeds and thoughts, this might perhaps be so.
But Justice looked upon and dignified him neither when he fled the darkness from his mother, nor in his nurture, nor ever when he grew to manhood, nor in the gathering of hair of his beard.
Nor indeed in the ill-treatment of his fatherland do I think she stands near him now.
Truly then would Justice be falsely named in all justice, consorting with a man all-daring in his mind.
Trusting in these things I will go and I myself will stand against him.
Who else is more just?
I will stand as ruler against ruler, and brother against brother, as enemy with enemy.
Bring as quickly as possible greaves, defenses against spear and stones.
Do not, dearest of men, child of Oedipus, become like in temper to him who is spoken of most badly.
But it is enough for Cadmean men to come to hands with Argives.
For blood is purifying.
But death of two men, blood brothers, thus self-slaughtered, there is no old age of this pollution.
If indeed someone should bear evil, let it be without shame.
For gain is only among the dead.
But of evil and base things you will speak no good report.
What do you intend, child?
Do not let spirit-filling, spear-raging ruin carry you away.
But cast out the beginning of evil passion.
Since god truly urges the matter, let the whole race of Laius, detested by Phoebus, having obtained the wave of Cocytus, go down the wind.
A raw-biting desire urges you too much to accomplish a bitter-fruited slaughter of blood not lawful.
For the hateful, wretched curse of my dear father sits near me with dry unweeping eyes, speaking of gain prior to later death.
But you, do not urge yourself on.
You will not be called a coward, having managed your life well.
Does not the Fury with black aegis go out of the house whenever the gods receive a sacrifice from the hands?
But by the gods already somehow we have been disregarded, and favor from us perishing is wondered at.
Why then would we still fawn upon destructive fate?
Now when it stands near you;
Since the divinity of will may perhaps come changed in a chronical turning with a gentler wind.
But now it still boils.
For the curses of Oedipus boiled over.
And too true are the visions of dream phantasms, dividers of paternal possessions.
Obey women, although not loving them nevertheless.
You might say something of what could be accomplished.
Nor is it necessary to be long.
Do not go yourself on these roads to the seventh gates.
You will surely not blunt me, sharpened, by word.
However, god honors victory even if bad.
It is not necessary for a heavy-armed man to love this word.
But do you wish to pluck your own brother's blood?
If gods grant it, you would not escape evils.
I shudder at the house-destroying goddess, not like the gods, the all-true prophetess of evil, the prayer-fulfilling Fury of the father, that she fulfill the angry curses of mad-minded Oedipus.
And this child-destroying strife urges [it] on.

And a foreign stranger allots shares, a Chalybian colonist from Scythia, a bitter divider of possessions, raw-minded iron, having shaken the lot for them to inhabit as much land as they can hold even in death, being shareless of the great plains.
But when they die self-slaughtered by their own hands, and the earth's dust drinks the black-clotted murderous blood, who could provide purifications, who could wash them?
Oh new toils of the house mingled with ancient evils.
For I speak of an ancient transgression with swift punishment.
And it remains unto the third generation.
When Laius, in defiance of Apollo who spoke three times in the central Pythian oracles that dying without offspring he would save the city...
But mastered by loving witlessness he begot death for himself, father-killing Oedipus, who having sown the holy field of his mother, where he was reared, a bloody root, endured it.
Madness brought the frenzied bride and groom together.
And like a sea it brings a wave of evils.
The one falling, another three-crested it raises up, which gurgles even around the stern of the city.
And between, defense stretches by a little space, a tower in width.
And I fear lest the city be tamed along with the kings.
For heavy are the settlements of ancient curses fulfilling themselves.
And destructive things coming into being do not pass by.
And wealth of enterprising men, having grown too thick, brings a casting out from the stern.
For whom of men did gods and fellow-hearth-dwellers of the city and the thronging gathering of mortals admire so much then as they honored Oedipus, who removed the man-seizing fate from the land?
But when he, wretched, became sensible of his miserable marriage, bearing it ill with maddened heart he accomplished double evils.
With a father-slaying hand he was bereft of his eyes, better than children.
And against the children he launched curses angry at his wild nurture, alas, bitter-tongued curses, and that they sometime divide the possessions with iron-wielding hand.
But now I tremble lest the swift-footed Fury fulfill [them].
Take courage, children nurtured by mothers.
This city has escaped the yoke of slavery.
The boasts of violent men have fallen.
And the city is in calm, and did not receive water despite the many blows of the surge.
And the tower protects, and we fenced the gates with trustworthy single-fighting champions.
Most things are well at six gates.
But the seventh lord Apollo, the reverend leader of seven, chose for himself, fulfilling the ancient ill-counsels of Laius for the race of Oedipus.
And what further new thing is there for the city?
The city has been saved.
But the kings of the same seed... who are they?
And what did you say?
I am out of my mind with fear of the word.
Being sensible, listen now.
The children of Oedipus... Woe is me wretched, I am a prophet of the evils.
And not doubtfully indeed laid low... do the two lie there?
Heavy things, but speak nevertheless.
The men have died by self-slaying hands.
Thus by brotherly hands were they killed together?
So common was the divinity to both alike.
And he himself destroys indeed the ill-fated race.
Such things are present to rejoice at and to weep for.
[Rejoice for] the city doing well, but the leaders, the two generals, have divided the whole possession of goods with hammered Scythian iron.
And they will have what land they take in burial, being carried unhappily according to the prayers of their father.
The city has been saved.
But the earth has drunk the blood of the two kings of the same seed by mutual slaughter.
Oh great Zeus and city-protecting divinities, who indeed protect these towers of Cadmus, should I rejoice and shout out for the unharmed savior of the city...
Or should I weep for the miserable and unfortunate childless war-leaders?
Who truly rightly according to name and full of strife perished by impious intent.
Oh black and complete curse of the race and of Oedipus, an evil chill falls around my heart.
Like a Thyiad, I made a song for the tomb, hearing of the dead dripping with blood, dying unhappily.
Truly ill-omened is this concert of the spear.
It has accomplished its deed, and the prayerful speech from the father did not fail.
And the disobedient counsels of Laius have lasted through.
And there is anxiety concerning the city.
The oracles are not blunted.
Oh much-groaning ones, you have wrought this incredible thing.
And lamentable woes came not in word.
These things are self-evident, the messenger's word is clear before our eyes.
Twofold anxieties, twin-manly evils, self-slaughtered, these sufferings are perfectly two-fold.
What should I say?
What else indeed than toils of toils, dwellers at the hearth of the house?

But, oh friends, row down the wind of lamentation the conducting stroke of hands about the head, which always crosses Acheron, the black-sailed mission-ship, the untrodden by Apollo, the sunless, all-receiving, to the unseen shore.
But these have come for a bitter matter, Antigone and Ismene, a lament for their two brothers.
I think that they will let forth a grief not doubtfully worthy from their lovely deep-bosomed breasts.
But it is right for us, before the ill-sounding report, to shout the hymn of the Fury and to sing the hostile paean of Hades.
Alas, most unfortunate sisters of all who put a band around their robes, I weep, I groan, and there is no deceit so that I do not shrill loudly from my heart truly.
Alas, alas, ill-minded, distrusted by friends and untiring of evils, you having taken the paternal home, wretched ones with the spear.
Wretched indeed are they who found wretched deaths for the ruin of the house.
Alas, alas, you destroyers of the house's walls and seeing bitter monarchy, now you have been reconciled by the sword.
And too truly the revered Fury of father Oedipus has brought it to pass.
Struck through their left sides, struck indeed, through their same-wombed sides! Alas, divine ones, alas, curses of opposing deaths!
You speak of a piercing blow to houses and bodies, [I tell of] them struck with unutterable wrath and by the curse of a father with a not divided fate.
And the groan penetrates the city too, the towers groan, the husband-loving plain groans.
And possessions remain for their descendants, through which, for the ill-fated ones, through which strife came and the end of death.
And keen of heart, they divided the possessions so as to receive an equal share.
But for the mediator, there is no blame from friends, nor is Ares graceful.
Smitten by iron they are thus, and smitten by iron those await them, perhaps someone might say, who?
The allotments of their paternal tombs.

This heart-rending lament sends forth the very loud sound of our house, self-groaning, self-suffering, thinking of enemies, not rejoicing, truly shedding tears from the mind, which shrinks as I weep for these two princes.
And it is possible to say over the wretched ones how they wrought many things for the citizens and the ranks of all the foreigners, causing much destruction in battle.
Unfortunate among them is she who bore them, before all women as many as are called child-bearers.
Having made her own child her husband, she bore these men, and they thus ended by mutually slaughtering hands of the same seed.
They are indeed of the same seed and utterly destroyed, by unkind severings, in maddened strife, in the end of the quarrel.
And the hatred has ceased, and their life has been mingled in the blood-soaked earth.
And very truly they are of the same blood.
The stranger from the sea, rushed from the fire, sharpened iron, is a bitter resolver of strife.
And Ares is a bitter, bad divider of possessions, making the curse of the father true.
The wretched ones have a portion, having obtained god-given woes.
And under the body will be wealth of earth, an abyss.
Alas, you have adorned the race with many toils.
And at the end the Curses shouted out the piercing song of the race put to flight in total rout.
And a trophy of Ruin stands at the gates, in which they were striking, and the divinity, having conquered the two, ceased.
Being struck, you struck.
And you died, having killed.
By the spear you killed, and by the spear you died, miserable in toil.
Miserable in suffering.
Let the lament go forth.
Let the tear go forth.
You lie before [us] having killed.
My mind is mad with wailing.
And inside my heart groans.
Alas, alas, you, all-tearful.
And you again also utterly wretched.
You perished by a friend.
And you killed a friend.
Double things to say—double to see—these pains of those near.
Brothers near brothers.
Oh Fate, giver of heavy gifts, miserable, and revered shade of Oedipus, black Fury, truly you are someone of great strength.
Sufferings hard to look upon... he showed to me after exile.
And he did not return as he killed.
But being saved, he lost his life.
He lost it indeed too much.
And he took this one away.
Wretched race!
Wretched suffering!
Mournful cares of the same blood.
Moist with triple-hurled woes.
Oh Fate, heavy-giving, miserable, and revered shade of Oedipus, black Fury, truly you are someone of great strength.
You surely know her, passing through... and you learned not later... when you came down to the city, an opponent to this spear.
Destructive things to say.
And destructive things to see.
Oh toil—Oh evils—to the house and the land.
And before all, to me.
And indeed the future is for me.
Oh, oh, oh lord of mournful evils.
Oh most mournful of all.
Oh, oh, being possessed by madness in ruin.
Oh, oh, where shall we place them in the earth?
Oh, where it is most honored.
Oh, oh, a bane lying beside their father.
It is necessary for me to report things seeming good and decided to the counselors of the people of this Cadmean city.
It seemed good to bury this Eteocles on account of his goodwill towards the land in its friendly excavations.
For hating the enemy he chose death in the city, and being holy and without blame regarding his paternal rites, he has died where it is noble for the young to die.
Thus indeed about this man it has been ordered to speak.

But the brother of this man, this corpse of Polynices, [it has been ordered] to cast out unburied, prey for dogs, as being an overturner of the land of Cadmeans, if some one of the gods had not stood in the way to his spear.
And even dying he will obtain pollution of the ancestral gods, whom dishonoring, casting in a foreign army, this man was taking the city.

Thus it seems best to take this penalty: to be buried dishonorably by winged birds, and neither to have the handiworks of raising a mound attend him nor to reverence him with sharp-singing wailings, but to be unhonored by a funeral from friends.
Such things seemed good to this office of the Cadmeans.
And I speak to the leaders of the Cadmeans.
Unless someone else wishes to join in burying this man, I will bury him and expose myself to danger, burying my brother, and I am not ashamed to hold this impious lawlessness against the city.
Terrible is our common parentage, from which we sprang, from a wretched mother and an unfortunate father.
Therefore, my soul, though wishing, shares evils with him, though living, with my dead kinsman in spirit.
No, nor shall hungry wolves tear his flesh.
Let no one suppose so.
For I, a woman though I am, will contrive a tomb and burial mounds for him, bringing (earth) in the fold of a linen garment.
And I myself will cover him, lest anyone should suppose otherwise again.
Be of good cheer; an effective contrivance shall be at hand.
I warn you, city, not to commit these acts of violence.
I warn you not to make excessive proclamations to me.
The people, having escaped evils, are indeed harsh.
You are harsh.
But this man shall not be unburied.
But the one whom the city loathes, will you honor with burial?
The things of this man have already been highly honored by the gods.
Not so, at least not before he exposed this land to danger.
Suffering badly, he gave bad things in return.
But this deed was against all instead of one.
Strife, the youngest of the gods, determines the matter.
I will bury this man.
Do not speak at length.
But be self-willed, and I prohibit you.
Alas, alas!
O loudly boasting and race-destroying Keres, Furies, who utterly destroyed the race of Oedipus, what can I suffer?
And what can I do?
And what can I contrive?
How shall I dare neither to mourn you nor to send you forth to the tomb?
But I am afraid and shrink away because of the fear of the citizens.
But you, however, shall be granted many mourners.
But that wretched man goes on, having the lonely lamentation of his sister.
Who then would persuade them of these things?
Let the city do or not do something to those who mourn Polyneices.
We will go and these women, acting as escorts, will join in burying him.
For this sorrow is common to our family, and the city, at different times, praises what is just otherwise.
But we, together with this man, are with the city, just as the city and justice jointly praise it.
For after the blessed gods and the might of Zeus, this man warded off the Kadmeian city, lest it be utterly overthrown nor flooded by an alien wave of men.
